page.title: United States women's national under-23 soccer team

revisions.rev:
{{Infobox national football team | Name = United States U-23 Women's National Team | Badge = | Nickname = ''The Yanks''
''The Stars and Stripes''
''The Red, White, and Blue'' | Association = [[United States Soccer Federation]] | Confederation = [[CONCACAF]] ([[North America]]) | FIFA Trigramme = USA | Coach = {{flagicon|NIR}} {{flagicon|USA}} [[Bill Irwin (footballer)|Bill Irwin]] | Asst Manager = | Captain = | Most caps = | Top scorer = | FIFA Rank = | FIFA max = | FIFA max date = | FIFA min = | FIFA min date = | pattern_la1 = _left_usa2 | pattern_b1 = _USAF2 | pattern_ra1 = _right_usa2 | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = FFFFFF | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = FFFFFF | pattern_la2 = _left_usa1 | pattern_b2 = _USAF1 | pattern_ra2 = _right_usa1 | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = 002868 | socks2 = 002868 | First game = | Largest win = | Largest loss = | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = | Olympic apps = | Olympic first = | Olympic best = | Algarve cup apps = | Algarve cup first = | Algarve cup best = | Regional name = [[Nordic Cup]] | Regional cup apps = 12 | Regional cup first = [[1997 Nordic Cup|1997]] | Regional cup best = Winners ([[1997 Nordic Cup|1997]], [[1999 Nordic Cup|1999]], [[2000 Nordic Cup|2000]], [[2001 Nordic Cup|2001]], [[2002 Nordic Cup|2002]], [[2003 Nordic Cup|2003]], [[2004 Nordic Cup|2004]], [[2005 Nordic Cup|2005]], [[2007 Nordic Cup|2007]], [[2008 Nordic Cup|2008]]) | type = women }} The '''United States U-23 women's national soccer team''' is a youth [[association football|soccer]] team operated under the auspices of [[United States Soccer Federation|U.S. Soccer]]. Its primary role is the development of players in preparation for the full Women's National Team. The team's most recent major tournament was the [[2008 Nordic Cup]], in which the United States team won 3-0 over Germany. The team competes in a variety of competitions, including the annual [[Nordic Cup]], which is the top competition for this age group.http://www.ussoccer.com/articles/viewArticle.jsp_12189697.html The current head coach is [[Bill Irwin (footballer)|Bill Irwin]]. ==History== ===Beginnings as a U-20 program=== The United States U-23 team has been active since 1989, however it was run as a U-20 team from its inception until 1998.2009 WNT U.S. Soccer Media Guide Its main goal was to prepare college players for the step up to international soccer. Women had no viable opportunities to enhance their playing abilities, aside from overseas, since the [[United States]] lacked a top-level domestic league during this time. ===The switch to U-21=== In 1998, [[United States Soccer Federation]] decided to make the team a U-21 team in order to give women a higher level of play to better prepare them for the full National Team. In accordance with this strategy, the U-21 team frequently rostered "over-aged" players in the U-21 training camps, as well as the [[Nordic Cup]]. It remained a U-21 team from 1998 through 2008. ===Competing as a U-23 team=== 2008 saw the change of the USA's oldest youth national team moved to the U-23 level. The move was made by the [[United States Soccer Federation]] in response to age-level changes [[FIFA]] had made to its oldest women's youth competition, now named [[FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup]]. The age limit was raised from being a U-19 tournament to a U-20 tournament. This change, coupled with a newly introduced U-23 age limit to the [[Nordic Cup]], prompted the USSF to rethink and eventually change the youth development team. The team continues to serve as a stepping-stone for collegiate and post-collegiate players to the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States Women's National Team]].http://ussoccer.com/teams/youth/index.jsp.html However, a new ally has appeared in order to further develop players — the new top-flight women's league, [[Women's Professional Soccer]], which kicked off in 2009. While many of the post-collegiate players play in this new league to develop their game, the U-23's turned focus on college players who are out of season and not yet WPS-eligible. ==Current players== ===2011 Four Nations Tournament roster=== The U-23 women competed in the Four Nations Tournament against the U-23 teams of [[England women's national football team|England]], [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]], and [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden]], Feb. 21-March 2, 2011. {{nat fs g start}} {{nat fs g player|no=1|pos=GK|name=[[Adrianna Franch]]|age={{birth date and
